title: Secure by default
text:
Security by default, in "<a href="Computer%20software">software</a>", means that the <a href="Default%20%28computer%20science%29">default</a> configuration settings are the most <a href="Computer%20security">secure</a> settings possible, which are not necessarily the most <a href="Usability">user-friendly</a> settings. In many cases, security and user-friendliness are evaluated based on both <a href="Risk%20analysis%20%28engineering%29">risk analysis</a> and <a href="Usability%20testing">usability tests</a>. This leads to the discussion of "what" the most secure settings are. As a result, the precise meaning of "secure by default" remains undefined.
In a <a href="network%20operating%20system">network operating system</a>, this typically means first and foremost that there are no listening INET(6) domain <a href="Internet%20socket">sockets</a> after installation; that is, no open <a href="TCP%20and%20UDP%20port">network ports</a>. This can be checked on the local <a href="Computer">machine</a> with a tool like <a href="netstat">netstat</a> and remotely with a <a href="port%20scanner">port scanner</a> such as <a href="nmap">nmap</a>. As a general rule, a secure <a href="Computer%20networking">network</a> is only as secure as the least secure <a href="Node%20%28networking%29">node</a> in the entire network.
If a <a href="Computer%20program">program</a> uses secure configuration settings by default, the <a href="User%20%28computing%29">user</a> will be better protected. However, not all users consider security and may be obstructed by secure settings. A common example is whether or not blank <a href="password">password</a>s are allowed for <a href="Logging%20%28computer%20security%29">login</a>. Not everyone can, or is willing to, type or memorize a password.
Another way to secure a program or system is through <a href="Abstraction%20%28computer%20science%29">abstraction</a>, where the user has presented an interface in which the user cannot (or is discouraged to) cause (accidental) <a href="data%20loss">data loss</a>. This, however, can lead to less functionality or reduced flexibility. Having user control preferences does not typically cause this but at the cost of having a larger part of the <a href="user%20interface">user interface</a> for configuration controls.
Some <a href="Server%20%28computing%29">server</a>s or <a href="Peripheral%20device">device</a>s that have an <a href="authentication">authentication</a> system, have default <a href="User%20%28computing%29">usernames</a> and passwords. If not properly changed, anyone who knows the default configuration can successfully <a href="Authentication">authenticate</a>. For non-unique defaults, this practice would violate the principle of 'security by default'.
Operating systems.
<a href="OpenBSD">OpenBSD</a> claims to be the only <a href="operating%20system">operating system</a> that is fully secure by default. This, however, does not mean it is inherently the most secure operating system. This is because that depends on the definition of an <a href="operating%20system">operating system</a>. There are many operating systems that are not capable of networking with other systems, and when considering the amount of network-based <a href="Compromise%23Security">security compromises</a> today, one can argue such an operating system is more secure. OpenBSD is a <a href="network%20operating%20system">network operating system</a>.
<a href="Ubuntu">Ubuntu</a> is a <a href="Linux%20distribution">Linux distribution</a> aimed at <a href="Desktop%20computer">desktop</a> users that hides the <a href="Superuser">administrative</a> <a href="User%20%28computing%29">account</a> by default and only allows the first user to gain <a href="System%20administrator%23Duties%20of%20a%20system%20administrator">administrative privileges</a> for certain system tasks (such as <a href="Installation%20%28computer%20programs%29">installing</a> system updates, and managing <a href="disk%20drive">disk drive</a>s). <a href="macOS">macOS</a> does not hide this account, but users with limited rights can still fully utilise the system. 
<a href="Microsoft%20Windows">Microsoft Windows</a> and <a href="Linspire">Linspire</a> have been criticised for allowing the user to have administrative privileges without warning—a potential threat to the system. <a href="Windows%20Vista">Windows Vista</a> and subsequent versions of Windows attempt to remedy this situation through its <a href="User%20Account%20Control">User Account Control</a> system.
